Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Game-Based Learning for Organic Chemistry Using Mechanisms
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project answers the call that science students go beyond memorizing facts to understand content on a deeper, conceptual level. In chemistry, this goal is particularly difficult to achieve because the underlying concepts describe the behaviors of particles that are not directly observable to students. College instructors are also under added pressure to transform their teaching methods to help ensure student retention and success. In the subject area of organic chemistry, this transformation is even more important, due to the relatively high fail-rate in the course, especially for under-represented minorities and first generation students. The mobile learning tools and data collection platform in this project would help to solve both of these issues with an innovative method for intuitive learning and assessment which helps to make molecules and reactions come alive with game-based mobile applications. The game apps are playable by students of all ages, so the concepts of organic chemistry, as well as other science courses, become familiar and accessible as early as middle school. The broader vision is to open the pipeline for students to progress into STEM careers which have been difficult to reach in the past.

This project makes the theoretical touchable for organic chemistry students by building mobile game-based learning tools based on mechanisms, a key underlying concept used to teaching the course. This project will produce the Mechanisms suite of game apps, and bring an intuitive, tactile interface to learning chemistry. The research and development of this phase of the project will expand the user interaction model from Phase I to multiple modules of content for students. The data from the mobile learning tools will be synthesized with machine learning techniques to create an adaptive method to ensure the applications provide the appropriate level of challenge to the student learner. Clinical and longitudinal efficacy studies will be part of the research effort as the game modules are developed and released. The data platform will be optimized to integrate with multiple learning management systems and to be readily expandable to subjects beyond organic chemistry. The dashboard of the platform will allow both instructors and students to access the data and inform learning processes to achieve greater comprehension and success in the course. Commercialization will be achieved through direct-to-student downloads, subscriptions of the data platform by institutions, and licensing the technology to courseware providers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF-funded research project supported the design and development of two software applications for teaching and learning college-level organic chemistry: Mechanisms and ModelAR. These learning tools are also integrated with a web-based faculty dashboard that allows instructors to send assignments directly to the student device and returns assessment information back to the dashboard. In the academic year starting fall 2020, the system was being used in 50 colleges and universities throughout the U.S. and the over 50,000 users have registered accounts in the system at the time of this report (12/2020).

The game-based method for teaching organic chemistry reaction mechanisms helped students explore a difficult and important concept from both semesters of the college-level course. The backend data system of the Mechanisms app was used to evaluate hypothesis-driven learning and a peer-reviewed technology report on this research was published in the Journal of Chemical Education in November 2020. (The Shrewd Guess: Can a Software System Assist Students in Hypothesis-driven Learning for Organic Chemistry, https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jchemed.0c00246.)

The Phase IIB research project converted the molecular modeling of the ModelAR app from a native mobile application to a series of web-based interactive assessment modules, which could be embedded readily into any educational platform. In addition to a 3D modeling system, other interactives were designed and developed to help students explore theoretical models of chemistry, such as hybridization theory, molecular orbital theory, bond dissociation energies, Lewis structure diagrams, and VSEPR. Each of these interactives were developed to include three different modes of student interaction: present, explore, and assess. The Hybridization Explorer was the subject of a research study with 31 college students from three different midwestern universities. The results of this research showed an increase in confidence and conceptual understanding of hybridization and valence bond theory. The results of this study and the method of presenting concepts in the three different modes were described in a Journal of Chemical Education article published in December 2020. (From Abstract to Manipulable: The Hybridization Explorer, A Digital Interactive for Studying Orbitals, https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jchemed.0c00847.)

The final development of this project came as the pandemic of 2020 occurred and in-person college instruction was suspended, so teaching and learning took place through video-conference systems. Based on a survey of 234 instructors at both the high school and college-level, it was determined that there was a distinct void in the ability for instructors to teach using active learning in a remote environment. The team created a web-based method for students to collaborate with each other and with their instructor using the suite of the interactive assessment tools that was agnostic to the video conference system.

Commercialization of this suite of products and the collaborative platform developed from this project will be through agreements with content providers and publishers.
